Well here’s another place you can go
 Where everything flows

Some fans have theorized that this line is a subtle reference to the song “There’s a Place.”

While this claim has been contested, one Reddit user pointed out the following similarity:

“There’s a Place”:

There’s a place where I can go,
When I feel low…

“Glass Onion”:

Here’s another place you can go,
Where everything flows…
Looking through a glass onion

Cluesters in the “Paul is Dead” phenomenon believed that “Glass Onion” was a slang term for casket knobs. This clue came from DJ Russ Gibb, who informed people of the outdated slang term.

Within the context of the song, this interpretation makes sense: “looking through the bent backed tulips / to see how the other half lives / looking through a glass onion”. I personally cannot find proof that “Glass Onion” was once used as a term for casket knobs.
To see how the other half lives

“How the other half lives” is an expression coming from a photographic study in the late 1880s. Its goal was to expose the living conditions of impoverished people—conditions that the middle- and upper-classes were previously largely unaware of.
Looking through the bent back tulips

In her autobiography “Wonderful Tonight: George Harrison, Eric Clapton, and Me,” Pattie Boyd writes that they used to enjoy a restaurant in London in which the chef would do creative thing with flowers on your plate, including bending tulip petals backward. Hence, John’s line,

Looking through the bent back tulips.
Trying to make a dove-tail joint, yeah

“Dove Tail Joint” refers to woodworking joinery, where the sides of pieces are fitted to fit. This was the cornerstone of craft in the past, where they didn’t have the modern joints we have, or access to iron nails and brackets.



He could be alluding to making these disparate, ostensibly random and meaningless lines make sense.

He could also be referring to putting the four corners of the four Beatles back together.
I tell you, man, he living there still

“The Fool on the Hill” was allegedly about Maharishi Mahesh Yogi. He was the one who taught The Beatles meditation at his retreat in Rishikesh, India. (“Sexy Sadie” is another song by the Beatles where Yogi is the subject matter.)

He is still living with the same foolish mind frame and living the same lifestyle on “the hill” (Presumably referring to his ashram in India).
I told you ’bout the fool on the hill

Reference to the song “The Fool on the Hill”.

Unlike the previous two verses where the first lines begin by referencing a song written by John Lennon (“Strawberry Fields Forever” & “I Am the Walrus”, respectively), “The Fool on the Hill” was written by Paul McCartney.
I told you ’bout the walrus and me, man

Reference to the Beatles song “I Am the Walrus”. Lennon wrote the song.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RG73Pk1yUj8
You know that we’re as close as can be, man

In the next line John will claim Paul was the walrus all along. To say “you know that we’re as close as can be-man” is quite ironic considering their friendship began to dissolve during the recording of The White Album.

Although it was written in 1968, Lennon later claimed the line was written because he was intending to leave The Beatles.

Well, that was a joke. The line was put in partly because I was feeling guilty because I was with Yoko and I was leaving Paul. I was trying – I don’t know. It’s a very perverse way of saying to Paul, you know, ‘Here, have this crumb, this illusion – this stroke, because I’m leaving’.
-John Lennon

McCartney has also revealed that during the filming of Magical Mystery Tour, it was he who wore the Walrus costume for the song’s performance. It has been said that, although intended for Lennon, the costume was a better fit on McCartney.
Looking through a glass onion

This line begins with a reference to the Beatles song “I’m Looking Through You”.

Wikipedia defines a glass onion with the following definition:

large hand blown glass bottles used aboard sailing ships to hold wine or brandy. For increased stability on rough seas, the bottles were fashioned with a wide-bottom shape to prevent toppling, thus making the bottles look somewhat onion-shaped.

The lyrics to this song are filled with references to other Beatles songs and there are a lot of obscure lines thrown in for the sake of being red herrings.

John Lennon wrote this song, and was not fond of critics over analyzing his lyrics (these type of critics are sometimes referred to as pseuds). The glass onion serves as a metaphor for these critics. They’re looking through a glass onion trying to figure out some complex meaning behind every line in every song by The Beatles. They may think they’re onto something, but really it’s distorting their vision.
